<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of build_connection_chunked_response_footer:
```c
static enum MHD_Result
build_connection_chunked_response_footer (struct MHD_Connection *connection)
{
  char *buf;           /**< the buffer to write footers to */
  size_t buf_size;     /**< the size of the @a buf */
  size_t used_size;    /**< the used size of the @a buf */
  struct MHD_Connection *const c = connection; /**< a short alias */
  struct MHD_HTTP_Res_Header *pos;

  mhd_assert (connection->rp.props.chunked);
  /* TODO: allow combining of the final footer with the last chunk,
   * modify the next assert. */
  mhd_assert (MHD_CONNECTION_CHUNKED_BODY_SENT == connection->state);
  mhd_assert (NULL != c->rp.response);

  buf_size = connection_maximize_write_buffer (c);
  /* '5' is the minimal size of chunked footer ("0\r\n\r\n") */
  if (buf_size < 5)
    return MHD_NO;
  mhd_assert (NULL != c->write_buffer);
  buf = c->write_buffer + c->write_buffer_append_offset;
  mhd_assert (NULL != buf);
  used_size = 0;
  buf[used_size++] = '0';
  buf[used_size++] = '\r';
  buf[used_size++] = '\n';

  for (pos = c->rp.response->first_header; NULL != pos; pos = pos->next)
  {
    if (MHD_FOOTER_KIND == pos->kind)
    {
      size_t new_used_size; /* resulting size with this header */
      /* '4' is colon, space, linefeeds */
      new_used_size = used_size + pos->header_size + pos->value_size + 4;
      if (new_used_size > buf_size)
        return MHD_NO;
      memcpy (buf + used_size, pos->header, pos->header_size);
      used_size += pos->header_size;
      buf[used_size++] = ':';
      buf[used_size++] = ' ';
      memcpy (buf + used_size, pos->value, pos->value_size);
      used_size += pos->value_size;
      buf[used_size++] = '\r';
      buf[used_size++] = '\n';
      mhd_assert (used_size == new_used_size);
    }
  }
  if (used_size + 2 > buf_size)
    return MHD_NO;
  buf[used_size++] = '\r';
  buf[used_size++] = '\n';

  c->write_buffer_append_offset += used_size;
  mhd_assert (c->write_buffer_append_offset <= c->write_buffer_size);

  return MHD_YES;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: The remaining code fragments (variable declarations, mhd_assert checks such as connection->rp.props.chunked, state and response non-NULL assertions, the for-loop structure, the used_size updates guarded by the checks, and the final update of c->write_buffer_append_offset and its assertion) do not themselves invoke <string.h> functions and are protected by explicit bounds checks or internal assertions. Those constructs therefore do not need further investigation under MISRA C Rule 21.17. The listed fragments are the locations where string handling / buffer writes occur or where size arithmetic that affects those operations is performed, so they should be inspected to ensure memcpy and indexed writes cannot access memory beyond their source or destination object bounds.
